newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: ST LUKES SEEN POSTING SOLID YR PROFIT GAIN.
newsitem.headline: ST LUKES SEEN POSTING SOLID YR PROFIT GAIN.

text.p: Shopping mall owner St Lukes Group, under new management, is expected to post a solid gain in earnings when it reports its annual result on Thursday.
Analysts told Reuters they expected a profit, before interest on convertible notes, of between NZ$29-31 million for the June year, up from $28.69 million a year earlier.
The consensus was for a profit of around NZ$29.9 million.
Little change was likely in the immediate future until Westfield Holdings, which took over management in April, completed its strategic review, analysts said.
Contrary to media reports, St Lukes is not expected to go to the market for expansion funds in the short term, they added.

Analysts forecast the result on a pre-convertible note interest payment basis because the notes are reqarded as quasi equity. The notes are mandatory, so interest payments are seen in a similar light to dividends.
"At the moment I think they're going to say it's business as usual," said one Wellington analyst.
Future refurbishment was likely but the timing and size of such a programme would remain an unknown for the time being.
"Clearly the input of Westfield as manager is going to be pretty beneficial to the company," the analyst said.
Local retailers are treating Westfield, which has a reputation in Australia as an uncompromising landlord, with some trepidation.
Jeweller Michael Mill International said on Tuesday it was to soon meet with St Lukes' new managers.

"We believe their rent demands are unreasonable and we understand, in Australia, their modus," MHI's New Zealand managing director Howard Bretherton said. "We will argue every case as well as we can," he told a results briefing.
One Auckland analyst said he expected an outcome of around NZ$31 million but again, nothing out of the ordinary.
The slump in retail sales would have no impact on St Lukes, because their rents are reviewed every two years in arrears.
"They are currently getting rental growth from two years ago's retail sales growth," he said.
The proportion of St Lukes' earnings linked to its tenants' sales was also small, he said.
